column4: as you are the solver around here ;)  do you know whether this is save todo? http://linuxfud.wordpress.com/2007/02/14/how-to-reset-ubuntugnome-settings-to-defaults-without-re-installing/
it may work, but it may also erase a lot of useful configurations. If you only want to reset the panel, or some other application, you may edit something more specific like gconf
but I can't login anymore after I deleted .gnome2/keyrings :f :D I think it's my only solution
oh, you did it already, and only now you are asking if it's safe enough?! He he! You could probably reinstall. Or try to reinstall gnome?
nono :D I did the keyrings thing to avoid the annoying message @ login, but I erased a litle bit to much :D
and I think resetting gnome is the only solution, hence the link
you followed some tutorial to avoid some "annoying message at login"?
yes in some way and I never do it again, :D I can say I know ubuntu quite well and I do know when something can be trust or not, only the .gnome2 dir is unknown terrain for me :D

but what did you do exactly? I see no "annoying message". I do remember some distributions ago, may be 3, the password was asked to connect to activate my wireless connection, one distribution later, it was no longer needed.
but now the annoying messages are my problem not anymore :D as I can't login anyway
yes, perhaps something like that.
that would be "reinstall", so it reinstalls.
sudo aptitude reinstall ubuntu-desktop, can you post in a pastebin the output of that? Perhaps you have messed up sources list.
okay
okay this was retarted :D  ubuntu-desktop is not installed and can't thus be reinstalled :D
so you didn't install ubuntu-desktop?
I removed it a couple of minutes ago
you should actually edit the file yourself, to make sure the file is correctly changed. Like "sudo nano /etc/apt/sources.list"
I just checked to be sure :p
I was expecting some awesome tool :D aptitude did know that too
oh, you should have mentioned that. You can probably download the alternate CD to install the packages you don't currently have, to reinstall gnome, for example
I have a bucn of cd's over here :p but I prefer doing it command line
but how are you going to reinstall gnome if you cannot use the internet. It's not possible, is it?
I just need to unlock my network :D
